title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
text: privacyR package helps anonymize sensitive data healthcare research datasets. provides tools protect patient privacy keeping data useful analysis.

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
code: # Install from CRAN install.packages("privacyR")

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
text: Anonymize patient IDs keeping referential integrity (IDs get anonymized value):
code: library(privacyR)  # Original patient IDs patient_ids <- c("P001", "P002", "P003", "P001", "P002") print(patient_ids) #> [1] "P001" "P002" "P003" "P001" "P002"  # Anonymize IDs anonymized_ids <- anonymize_id(patient_ids, seed = 123) print(anonymized_ids) #>          P001          P002          P003          P001          P002  #> "ID_uhjsB46B" "ID_4cQBb8Pk" "ID_meDL69Fd" "ID_uhjsB46B" "ID_4cQBb8Pk"  # Note: Same original IDs map to same anonymized IDs

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
code: # Original names names <- c("John Doe", "Jane Smith", "Bob Johnson", "John Doe") print(names) #> [1] "John Doe"    "Jane Smith"  "Bob Johnson" "John Doe"  # Anonymize names anonymized_names <- anonymize_names(names, seed = 123) print(anonymized_names) #>           John Doe         Jane Smith        Bob Johnson           John Doe  #> "Patient_NDg84Pt8" "Patient_ufNUJoZm" "Patient_ADANaKPi" "Patient_NDg84Pt8"

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
text: Two methods available: shifting rounding.

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
text: Shifting moves dates amount, preserving relative time differences:
code: # Original dates dates <- as.Date(c("2020-01-15", "2020-03-20", "2020-06-10")) print(dates) #> [1] "2020-01-15" "2020-03-20" "2020-06-10"  # Shift dates shifted_dates <- anonymize_dates(dates, method = "shift", seed = 123) print(shifted_dates) #> [1] "2020-03-04" "2020-05-08" "2020-07-29"  # Relative differences are preserved diff_original <- as.numeric(dates[2] - dates[1]) diff_shifted <- as.numeric(shifted_dates[2] - shifted_dates[1]) cat("Original difference:", diff_original, "days\n") #> Original difference: 65 days cat("Shifted difference:", diff_shifted, "days\n") #> Shifted difference: 65 days

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
text: Rounding reduces precision grouping dates buckets (day, week, month, year, etc.):
code: # Round to month rounded_month <- anonymize_dates(dates, method = "round",                                   granularity = "month", seed = 123) print(rounded_month) #> [1] "2020-01-01" "2020-03-01" "2020-06-01"  # Round to year rounded_year <- anonymize_dates(dates, method = "round",                                  granularity = "year", seed = 123) print(rounded_year) #> [1] "2020-01-01" "2020-01-01" "2020-01-01"

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
code: # Original locations locations <- c("New York, NY", "Los Angeles, CA", "Chicago, IL",                 "New York, NY") print(locations) #> [1] "New York, NY"    "Los Angeles, CA" "Chicago, IL"     "New York, NY"  # Generalize locations generalized <- anonymize_locations(locations, method = "generalize", seed = 123) print(generalized) #>        New York, NY     Los Angeles, CA         Chicago, IL        New York, NY  #> "Location_ggyQKpzW" "Location_hybAy7Aq" "Location_DpYfTU6h" "Location_ggyQKpzW"  # Or remove locations entirely removed <- anonymize_locations(locations, method = "remove", seed = 123) print(removed) #> [1] "[Location Removed]" "[Location Removed]" "[Location Removed]" #> [4] "[Location Removed]"

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
text: anonymize_dataframe() function provides convenient way anonymize entire data frames:
code: # Create sample patient data patient_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = c("P001", "P002", "P003", "P001"),   name = c("John Doe", "Jane Smith", "Bob Johnson", "John Doe"),   dob = as.Date(c("1980-01-15", "1975-03-20", "1990-06-10", "1980-01-15")),   admission_date = as.Date(c("2020-01-10", "2020-02-15", "2020-03-20", "2020-01-10")),   location = c("New York, NY", "Los Angeles, CA", "Chicago, IL", "New York, NY"),   diagnosis = c("Hypertension", "Diabetes", "Hypertension", "Hypertension"),   age = c(40, 45, 30, 40) )  print("Original data:") #> [1] "Original data:" print(patient_data) #>   patient_id        name        dob admission_date        location    diagnosis #> 1       P001    John Doe 1980-01-15     2020-01-10    New York, NY Hypertension #> 2       P002  Jane Smith 1975-03-20     2020-02-15 Los Angeles, CA     Diabetes #> 3       P003 Bob Johnson 1990-06-10     2020-03-20     Chicago, IL Hypertension #> 4       P001    John Doe 1980-01-15     2020-01-10    New York, NY Hypertension #>   age #> 1  40 #> 2  45 #> 3  30 #> 4  40  # Anonymize the entire data frame anonymized_data <- anonymize_dataframe(patient_data, seed = 123)  print("\nAnonymized data:") #> [1] "\nAnonymized data:" print(anonymized_data) #>    patient_id             name        dob admission_date          location #> 1 ID_yy4R3rcM Patient_az6MEMKn 1980-10-20     2020-10-15 Location_j5VxZULh #> 2 ID_wegx46wW Patient_VrFXRGmZ 1975-12-24     2020-11-20 Location_DDYWM3yf #> 3 ID_2wEutqA2 Patient_ipQ2Y8Di 1991-03-16     2020-12-24 Location_xW5ux6EG #> 4 ID_yy4R3rcM Patient_az6MEMKn 1980-10-20     2020-10-15 Location_j5VxZULh #>      diagnosis   age #> 1 Hypertension 40-49 #> 2     Diabetes 40-49 #> 3 Hypertension 30-39 #> 4 Hypertension 40-49

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
text: default, anonymize_dataframe() automatically detects columns based naming patterns data types:
code: # The function automatically detects: # - ID columns: patient_id, subject_id, etc. # - Name columns: name, patient_name, etc. # - Date columns: date, dob, admission_date, etc. # - Location columns: location, address, city, etc.  # You can also manually specify columns manual_anon <- anonymize_dataframe(   patient_data,   id_cols = "patient_id",   name_cols = "name",   date_cols = c("dob", "admission_date"),   location_cols = "location",   auto_detect = FALSE,   seed = 123 )

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
text: Seeds reproducibility: seed parameter optional (default: NULL). seed = NULL, package still maintains referential integrity using deterministic hash-based approach, inputs always produce outputs. explicit reproducibility across sessions, provide seed: Note: package always restores R session’s random number generator state anonymization, random number generation never affected. Referential integrity maintained automatically - original values get anonymized values, preserves relationships data. works even seed = NULL. Date anonymization: Use “shift” preserve relative time differences Use “round” reduce precision (e.g., month-year format) Location anonymization: Use “generalize” keep location info Use “remove” location sensitive Validate results - make sure anonymized data still works analysis.
code: anonymized <- anonymize_dataframe(data, seed = 12345)

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
text: Keep mind: Complete anonymization difficult achieve may need additional privacy measures depending use case Consider consulting privacy experts sensitive data Review relevant regulations (HIPAA, GDPR, etc.) jurisdiction

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization with privacyR
text: information, see package documentation:
code: ?anonymize_dataframe help(package = "privacyR")

code: @Manual{,   title = {privacyR: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization},   author = {Vikrant Dev Rathore},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.0.1},   url = {https://vikrant31.github.io/PrivacyR/}, }

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization
text: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization R R package anonymizing sensitive patient research data. Helps protect privacy keeping data useful analysis.

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization
code: # Install from CRAN install.packages("privacyR")

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization
code: library(privacyR)  # Anonymize a data frame patient_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = c("P001", "P002", "P003"),   name = c("John Doe", "Jane Smith", "Bob Johnson"),   dob = as.Date(c("1980-01-15", "1975-03-20", "1990-06-10")),   location = c("New York, NY", "Los Angeles, CA", "Chicago, IL") )  anonymized_data <- anonymize_dataframe(patient_data, seed = 123) print(anonymized_data)  # With UUID anonymization for stronger privacy anonymized_data_uuid <- anonymize_dataframe(patient_data, use_uuid = TRUE, seed = 123) print(anonymized_data_uuid)  # Month-year date anonymization anonymized_data <- anonymize_dataframe(patient_data,                                         date_method = "round",                                        date_granularity = "month_year") print(anonymized_data)

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization
text: Anonymize IDs, names, dates, locations, ages Maintains referential integrity (values get anonymized values) Auto-detects columns name patterns data types Short UUID support stronger privacy (default) Date anonymization month-year format (YYYYMM) Age bucketing (10-year HIPAA-compliant) Works data frames data.tables Dataset-specific anonymization (different datasets get different values)

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization
text: anonymization functions accept optional seed parameter (default: NULL). seed = NULL: package maintains referential integrity using deterministic hash-based approach. inputs always produce anonymized outputs, ensuring relationships data preserved. seed provided: get explicit control anonymization reproducibility across sessions. Global RNG state: package always restores R session’s random number generator state anonymization, random number generation never affected. can use package without providing seed, still maintain referential integrity automatically.

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization
text: anonymize_id() - Anonymize patient identifiers anonymize_names() - Anonymize patient names anonymize_dates() - Anonymize dates (shift round) anonymize_locations() - Anonymize geographic locations anonymize_dataframe() - Anonymize entire data frames

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization
text: See package vignette detailed examples usage:
code: vignette("privacyR")

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization
text: IMPORTANT: privacyR package aids anonymizing patient data, users must ensure compliance applicable regulations guidelines. author liable issues arising use package. Testing: package tested 1 million synthetic patient records ensure UUID uniqueness proper anonymization functionality. However, users validate anonymization results specific use cases datasets. Users pay close attention : - CDC Guidelines: CDC Data Privacy HIPAA - California Department Health Care Services: DHCS List HIPAA Identifiers - HIPAA Regulations: HHS De-identification Guidance package provided “” without warranty. Users assume full responsibility ensuring anonymized data meets regulatory requirements. Consult legal privacy experts needed.

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization
text: MIT

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization
text: use package research, please cite :
code: citation("privacyR")

title: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization
text: Contributions welcome! Please feel free submit issues pull requests.

title: Anonymize Age by Buckets — anonymize_age
text: Groups ages buckets privacy protection. Default uses 10-year buckets (0-9, 10-19, etc.) useful research. Ages 90+ grouped together.

title: Anonymize Age by Buckets — anonymize_age
code: anonymize_age(x, method = c("10year", "hipaa"), custom_buckets = NULL)

title: Anonymize Age by Buckets — anonymize_age
text: x numeric vector ages anonymize method Character string specifying bucketing method: "10year" (default) uses 10-year buckets: 0-9, 10-19, 20-29, 30-39, 40-49, 50-59, 60-69, 70-79, 80-89, 90+ "hipaa" uses HIPAA-compliant buckets: 0-17, 18-64, 65-89, 90+ custom_buckets Optional named numeric vector custom buckets. Format: c("0-9" = 9, "10-19" = 19, "20-29" = 29, "90+" = Inf)

title: Anonymize Age by Buckets — anonymize_age
text: character vector age buckets

title: Anonymize Age by Buckets — anonymize_age
code: ages <- c(25, 45, 67, 92, 15, 78) anonymize_age(ages)  # Uses 10-year buckets by default #> [1] "20-29" "40-49" "60-69" "90+"   "10-19" "70-79" anonymize_age(ages, method = "hipaa")  # Use HIPAA buckets #> [1] "18-64" "18-64" "65-89" "90+"   "0-17"  "65-89"

what: Anonymize Patient Data in a Data Frame — anonymize_dataframe
title: Anonymize Patient Data in a Data Frame — anonymize_dataframe
text: Main function anonymize patient data data frame data.table. Automatically detects anonymizes columns based data types naming patterns, can manually specify columns. Different datasets get different anonymized values better privacy.

title: Anonymize Patient Data in a Data Frame — anonymize_dataframe
code: anonymize_dataframe(   data,   id_cols = NULL,   name_cols = NULL,   date_cols = NULL,   location_cols = NULL,   age_cols = NULL,   auto_detect = TRUE,   detect_by_type = TRUE,   date_method = "shift",   date_granularity = "month",   location_method = "generalize",   age_method = "10year",   use_uuid = TRUE,   seed = NULL,   dataset_specific = TRUE )

title: Anonymize Patient Data in a Data Frame — anonymize_dataframe
text: data data frame data.table containing patient data id_cols Character vector column names containing patient IDs name_cols Character vector column names containing patient names date_cols Character vector column names containing dates location_cols Character vector column names containing locations age_cols Character vector column names containing ages auto_detect Logical, TRUE (default), automatically detects columns based data types common naming patterns detect_by_type Logical, TRUE (default), detects columns R data types (Date, character, etc.) addition name patterns date_method Method date anonymization: "shift" "round" (default: "shift"). Use "round" enable granularity options including "month_year" (YYYYMM format). date_granularity date rounding (date_method = "round"): "day", "week", "month", "month_year" (returns YYYYMM format, e.g., "202005"), "quarter", "year" (default: "month") location_method Method location anonymization: "remove" "generalize" age_method Method age anonymization: "10year" (default) uses 10-year buckets (0-9, 10-19, 20-29, ..., 80-89, 90+) better research utility, "hipaa" HIPAA-compliant buckets (0-17, 18-64, 65-89, 90+) use_uuid Logical, TRUE uses short UUIDs IDs, names, locations instead sequential identifiers (default: TRUE). Dates ages affected. seed optional seed reproducible anonymization. Different datasets still get different anonymized values even seed. dataset_specific Logical, TRUE (default), generates dataset-specific seeds different datasets get different anonymized values

title: Anonymize Patient Data in a Data Frame — anonymize_dataframe
text: data frame anonymized patient data (preserves data.table class input data.table)

title: Anonymize Patient Data in a Data Frame — anonymize_dataframe
code: # Basic usage with auto-detection patient_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = c("P001", "P002", "P003"),   name = c("John Doe", "Jane Smith", "Bob Johnson"),   dob = as.Date(c("1980-01-15", "1975-03-20", "1990-06-10")),   location = c("New York, NY", "Los Angeles, CA", "Chicago, IL"),   diagnosis = c("A", "B", "A") ) anonymize_dataframe(patient_data, seed = 123) #>    patient_id             name        dob          location diagnosis #> 1 ID_ouSbzEgq Patient_6k2nsVas 1980-02-23 Location_Q98vAvyL         A #> 2 ID_E9JiNTER Patient_7g3kma75 1975-04-28 Location_sBSspjmx         B #> 3 ID_H9dZM6iQ Patient_A7K9Ea9J 1990-07-19 Location_8MA8fu9H         A  # With month_year date granularity (YYYYMM format) anonymize_dataframe(patient_data, date_method = "round", date_granularity = "month_year") #>    patient_id             name    dob          location diagnosis #> 1 ID_w2EsGPA6 Patient_wfvcEyLg 198001 Location_BKPB9n3n         A #> 2 ID_qLcguMtS Patient_pA3Na8gU 197503 Location_peX4F6Vi         B #> 3 ID_apswz96L Patient_6mNgRVDu 199006 Location_zx9FzuBK         A  # Works with data.table if (requireNamespace("data.table", quietly = TRUE)) {   dt <- data.table::as.data.table(patient_data)   anonymize_dataframe(dt) } #>     patient_id             name        dob          location diagnosis #>         <char>           <char>     <Date>            <char>    <char> #> 1: ID_w2EsGPA6 Patient_wfvcEyLg 1980-09-10 Location_BKPB9n3n         A #> 2: ID_qLcguMtS Patient_pA3Na8gU 1975-11-14 Location_peX4F6Vi         B #> 3: ID_apswz96L Patient_6mNgRVDu 1991-02-04 Location_zx9FzuBK         A  # With UUID anonymization (default) anonymize_dataframe(patient_data, seed = 123) #>    patient_id             name        dob          location diagnosis #> 1 ID_ouSbzEgq Patient_6k2nsVas 1980-02-23 Location_Q98vAvyL         A #> 2 ID_E9JiNTER Patient_7g3kma75 1975-04-28 Location_sBSspjmx         B #> 3 ID_H9dZM6iQ Patient_A7K9Ea9J 1990-07-19 Location_8MA8fu9H         A  # Without UUID (sequential IDs) anonymize_dataframe(patient_data, use_uuid = FALSE, seed = 123) #>   patient_id         name        dob      location diagnosis #> 1     ID3663 Patient 3663 1980-02-23 Location 3663         A #> 2     ID3664 Patient 3664 1975-04-28 Location 3664         B #> 3     ID3665 Patient 3665 1990-07-19 Location 3665         A

title: Anonymize Dates — anonymize_dates
text: Anonymizes dates shifting random offset rounding specified granularity. Shifting preserves relative time differences.

title: Anonymize Dates — anonymize_dates
code: anonymize_dates(   x,   method = c("shift", "round"),   days_shift = NULL,   granularity = "month",   seed = NULL )

title: Anonymize Dates — anonymize_dates
text: x vector dates (Date, POSIXct, character can coerced Date) method Character string specifying anonymization method: "shift" (default) shifts dates random offset, "round" rounds dates specified granularity days_shift "shift" method: number days shift (default: random -365 365) granularity "round" method: "day", "week", "month", "month_year", "quarter", "year" (default: "month"). "month_year" returns character strings "YYYYMM" format (e.g., "202005" May 2020). seed optional seed reproducible anonymization

title: Anonymize Dates — anonymize_dates
text: Date vector anonymized dates (character vector "month_year" granularity)

title: Anonymize Dates — anonymize_dates
code: dates <- as.Date(c("2020-01-15", "2020-03-20", "2020-06-10")) anonymize_dates(dates, method = "shift", seed = 123) #> [1] "2020-03-04" "2020-05-08" "2020-07-29" anonymize_dates(dates, method = "round", granularity = "month") #> [1] "2020-01-01" "2020-03-01" "2020-06-01" anonymize_dates(dates, method = "round", granularity = "month_year") #> [1] "202001" "202003" "202006"

title: Anonymize Patient Identifiers — anonymize_id
text: Replaces patient identifiers anonymized versions maintaining referential integrity (IDs get anonymized value).

title: Anonymize Patient Identifiers — anonymize_id
code: anonymize_id(x, prefix = "ID", seed = NULL, use_uuid = TRUE)

title: Anonymize Patient Identifiers — anonymize_id
text: x vector identifiers anonymize (character, numeric, factor) prefix character string prefix anonymized IDs (default: "ID") seed optional seed reproducible anonymization use_uuid Logical, TRUE uses short UUIDs instead sequential IDs (default: TRUE).

title: Anonymize Patient Identifiers — anonymize_id
text: character vector anonymized identifiers

title: Anonymize Patient Identifiers — anonymize_id
code: ids <- c("P001", "P002", "P003", "P001") anonymize_id(ids) #>          P001          P002          P003          P001  #> "ID_KPHvJnAi" "ID_SPQFnmK7" "ID_AmV2nhjB" "ID_KPHvJnAi"  anonymize_id(ids, prefix = "PAT", seed = 123) #>           P001           P002           P003           P001  #> "PAT_uhjsB46B" "PAT_4cQBb8Pk" "PAT_meDL69Fd" "PAT_uhjsB46B"  anonymize_id(ids, use_uuid = FALSE, seed = 123)  # Use sequential IDs #>    P001    P002    P003    P001  #> "ID125" "ID126" "ID127" "ID125"

title: Anonymize Geographic Locations — anonymize_locations
text: Anonymizes geographic locations removing replacing generic labels. Maintains referential integrity (locations get value).

title: Anonymize Geographic Locations — anonymize_locations
code: anonymize_locations(   x,   method = c("remove", "generalize"),   prefix = "Location",   seed = NULL,   use_uuid = TRUE )

title: Anonymize Geographic Locations — anonymize_locations
text: x character vector locations anonymize method Character string specifying anonymization method: "remove" (default) removes location information, "generalize" replaces generic location labels prefix "generalize" method: prefix generic locations (default: "Location") seed optional seed reproducible anonymization use_uuid Logical, TRUE uses short UUIDs instead sequential IDs (default: TRUE). applies method = "generalize".

title: Anonymize Geographic Locations — anonymize_locations
text: character vector anonymized locations

title: Anonymize Geographic Locations — anonymize_locations
code: locations <- c("New York, NY", "Los Angeles, CA", "Chicago, IL") anonymize_locations(locations, method = "remove") #> [1] "[Location Removed]" "[Location Removed]" "[Location Removed]" anonymize_locations(locations, method = "generalize", seed = 123) #>        New York, NY     Los Angeles, CA         Chicago, IL  #> "Location_ggyQKpzW" "Location_hybAy7Aq" "Location_DpYfTU6h"  anonymize_locations(locations, method = "generalize",                      use_uuid = FALSE, seed = 123)  # Use sequential IDs #>    New York, NY Los Angeles, CA     Chicago, IL  #>  "Location 125"  "Location 126"  "Location 127"

title: Anonymize Patient Names — anonymize_names
text: Replaces patient names anonymized identifiers maintaining referential integrity (names get anonymized value).

title: Anonymize Patient Names — anonymize_names
code: anonymize_names(x, prefix = "Patient", seed = NULL, use_uuid = TRUE)

title: Anonymize Patient Names — anonymize_names
text: x character vector names anonymize prefix character string prefix anonymized names (default: "Patient") seed optional seed reproducible anonymization use_uuid Logical, TRUE uses short UUIDs instead sequential IDs (default: TRUE).

title: Anonymize Patient Names — anonymize_names
text: character vector anonymized names

title: Anonymize Patient Names — anonymize_names
code: names <- c("John Doe", "Jane Smith", "Bob Johnson") anonymize_names(names) #>           John Doe         Jane Smith        Bob Johnson  #> "Patient_sND3xPXV" "Patient_nCKLw9hL" "Patient_h4oP5N9d"  anonymize_names(names, prefix = "PAT", seed = 123) #>       John Doe     Jane Smith    Bob Johnson  #> "PAT_NDg84Pt8" "PAT_ufNUJoZm" "PAT_ADANaKPi"  anonymize_names(names, use_uuid = FALSE, seed = 123)  # Use sequential IDs #>      John Doe    Jane Smith   Bob Johnson  #> "Patient 125" "Patient 126" "Patient 127"

title: Generate Dataset-Specific Seed — generate_dataset_seed
text: Internal function generate seed based dataset content. ensures different datasets get different anonymized values even user-provided seed.

title: Generate Dataset-Specific Seed — generate_dataset_seed
code: generate_dataset_seed(data, user_seed = NULL)

title: Generate Dataset-Specific Seed — generate_dataset_seed
text: data dataset user_seed Optional user-provided seed

title: Generate Dataset-Specific Seed — generate_dataset_seed
text: numeric seed value

what: Generate Short UUID for Anonymization — generate_short_uuid
title: Generate Short UUID for Anonymization — generate_short_uuid
text: Internal function generate short, reproducible UUIDs anonymization. Uses hash-based approach ensure referential integrity (input always produces UUID) maintaining uniqueness across datasets.

title: Generate Short UUID for Anonymization — generate_short_uuid
code: generate_short_uuid(x, prefix = NULL, seed = NULL, length = 8)

title: Generate Short UUID for Anonymization — generate_short_uuid
text: x Character vector values anonymize prefix Optional prefix UUID (default: NULL) seed Dataset-specific seed reproducibility length Length random part (default: 8)

title: Generate Short UUID for Anonymization — generate_short_uuid
text: Character vector short UUIDs

title: privacyR: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization — privacyR-package
text: Tools anonymizing sensitive data healthcare research datasets. Helps protect patient privacy keeping data useful analysis.

title: privacyR: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization — privacyR-package
text: Main functions: anonymize_id - Anonymize patient identifiers anonymize_names - Anonymize patient names anonymize_dates - Anonymize dates (shift round) anonymize_locations - Anonymize geographic locations anonymize_age - Anonymize ages buckets anonymize_dataframe - Anonymize entire data frames

title: privacyR: Privacy-Preserving Data Anonymization — privacyR-package
text: Vikrant Dev Rathore

title: Version 1.0.1 (2025-11-22)
text: CRAN release: 2025-11-23

title: Version 1.0.1 (2025-11-22)
text: Critical fix: Replaced weak hash function UUID generation cryptographic hash (MD5) prevent duplicate UUIDs different patients large datasets Added robust hash function datasets 5 unique values Maintains backward compatibility: small datasets (≤5 unique values) use original hash method Now handles datasets 1 million+ records without collisions Added digest package required dependency robust hashing Maintains referential integrity (input → UUID) ensuring uniqueness

title: Version 1.0.1 (2025-11-22)
text: large datasets (>5 unique values): Uses MD5 hash via digest package small datasets (≤5 unique values): Uses original hash method (backward compatible) MD5 collision probability 1M records: ~10^-15 (negligible) functions using UUIDs (anonymize_id, anonymize_names, anonymize_locations) benefit fix

title: Version 1.0.0 (2024-11-09)
text: CRAN release: 2025-11-17

title: Version 1.0.0 (2024-11-09)
text: Fixed README.md remove reference DISCLAIMER file (CRAN compliance) Disclaimer text now README.md First stable release

title: Version 0.1.1 (2024-11-07)
text: Package renamed shadowR privacyR avoid CRAN name conflict Fixed LICENSE format CRAN compliance Updated CDC HIPAA URL reference Added DISCLAIMER .Rbuildignore

title: Version 0.1.0 (Initial Release)
text: Initial release privacyR package anonymize_id() function anonymizing patient identifiers anonymize_names() function anonymizing patient names anonymize_dates() function shift round methods anonymize_locations() function remove generalize methods anonymize_dataframe() function anonymizing entire data frames Comprehensive test suite using testthat Vignette detailed examples best practices Full roxygen2 documentation
